subject: Re: [junit] A case for adding logging of assertions to junit

messageBody:
On 2008-06-09, at 18:56 , CÃ©dric Beust ? wrote:
> I think the original poster wants a log of all the assertions that
> are being
> run. Whether the tests are simple (one assertion per test) or
> complex is an
> orthogonal issue.
>
I understand what the original poster wants, and I believe the issues
are related. I thought I made that clear in my message.
> This feature request has come up a few times on the TestNG mailing-
> list as
> well, and I have sometimes felt this need occasionally myself.
>
I understand that. I have also felt this need in the past. When I
observed that I could solve many of the same problems by writing
smaller, more focused tests, not only did I stop wanting to log
assertions, but my designs improved and I delivered more solid
features sooner. I believe that if JUnit logged its assertions, then
that would have robbed me of this experience.
> Think of it as another granularity level of insight inside your
> tests: if
> you want the big picture, you look at the HTML reports. If you want
> the
> fine picture, you look at the source. And if you want something in-
> between
> ("are we making sure the collection is the right size?"), you could
> use this
> hypothetical assert log without the source noise.
>
If the collection needs to be the right size, and if getting that
wrong is more than microscopically likely, then I write a test for it.
That's what I do and that's what I recommend others do.

Take care.
